oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Confederate's Return from "Disbanding the Confederate Army"

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Military Uniforms; Houses; Trees; Fences
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Books and reading - United States - History - 19th Century; Tarbell, Ida M. (Ida Minerva), 1857-1944
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Illustration by George Varian of a Confederate soldier leaning against a fence post gazing at a destroyed house. The caption underneath reads "The Confederate's Return - There was only the shell of the house." The image appears on page 537 of Ida M. Tarbell's "Disbanding of the Confederate Army" article. The text above the image discusses Confederate dealings with Mexico. The article appeared in McClure's Magazine.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: George Varian
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: McClure's Magazine was founded in 1893 and is often compared to Atlantic Monthly. It is credited with creating "muckraking" journalism. Ida M. Tarbell was an author best known for her book "The History of Standard Oil," which is given some of the credit for the Federal antitrust action against Standard Oil. A leading "muckraker," Tarbell often wrote for McClure's and The Standard. George Varian was an illustrator known for his works featuring American Western themes.
